Bottle. Pours hazy copper with average white head; good retention and some lacing. Aroma is sour fruit, yeast, spice, slight funk, and faint grassy hops. Flavor is light malt and hops with heavy fruit esters; tart finish. Medium body and warmth with medium/high carbonation.

Fresh 750ml bottle, courtesy blazer06.  This one pours a cloudy, golden orange color and topped by a small head of off white foam that slowly settles to a thin film and leaves a sudsy wash across the glass. The aroma is really nice showing a good amount of fresh peaches, apricots, and chardonnay grapes that add ample amount of citric acidity. The oak imparts notes of soured wood and vanilla to go with a big dose of floral hop bitterness in the back ground. The typical Cantillon funk is there, but the floral hop bitterness seems to overshadow it. The flavor follows suit and is initially oaky with vanilla up front and then followed by a huge dose of soured apricots and tart white grape skins. There is a good amount of vinous character from the grapes and oak and finishing with a good amount of bitterness from the dusty, floral hops. Really delicious stuff. The palate is quite substantial, which is a change from the typical Cantillon, and very dry and parching with tingling carbonation throughout. This is great tasting stuff, and I love the added hop component. This is a great brew and right up there with some of the other great Cantillon brews.
Floral lemon smell. Cloudy orange yellow amber color. Very dry and moderately acidic and sour. Lemon and floral flavors .
bottle at home 2005 drunk 2012 ... clear pink amber ... funky nose ... soft shoe leather ... tart foul and disgusting ... maybe it might make good vinegar .. apple skins ... but arg

RBAG 2012. Delicious lambic! Pours a hazy orange with a small to average size white head. Nice funky aroma. Flavours quite nice: funky with some lemon, yeast and a mild bitter finish -- yet its a simple version of the style making it really easy to drink but not as complex as most of the other Cantillons. I could drink a lot of this though.

Bottled in 2007.  The pour is dark brownish orange, with some yellow highlights in the bottom of the glass.  It has a huge white head that recedes quickly to a thin layer of foam on top that stays around for a considerable time.  The nose is old funky tennis shoes, earthy floral bouquet and soured apples.   Super complex flavor.  The first thing you experience is a sour punch followed buy a bittersweet rush transitioning to bitter and finishing with mouth puckering sour.  The mouthfeel on this beer is sharp yet fairly creamy, the aftertaste is superb and lingers for a long time.  This is a staple of Cantillon and one of my favorite beers, ever.

RBAG 2012. 2007 version. Poured out a light ambery orange colour with a small small head. The aroma is stellar as it always seems to be with Cantillon, green apple, lemon, light pepper, vineous, funk, unsweetened grapefruit and a bit musty. The flavour consists of this stuff that makes yummy happen: sour sour lemons, mustiness, small amount of watered down vinegar, grapefruit, hoppy goodness, apricots (Ive had unbearably sour apricots), I lied about the vinegar as it really puts out a painful bite, cheese. This is a wonderfully savouring and drinkable beer. Lovely aftertaste.

75cl bottle, 2007 vintage, bottled 15 Dec 2010, split with my wife. Pours an orange-yellow color with a big white head. Aroma is grassy, earth, yeast, lemon. Medium on the palate with soft carbonation. Flavor is sour, light tart, floral, a little citrus lemon, with a tart, floral finish. An amazingly interesting beer.

2007 bottle from thoreaulikegrl at Teresas, thank you. Pours amber oranfe with a small white head. The aroma is sweet, vinegary, and a bit tangy. The. flavor is sour and a bit tangy with a dry ending. This was the best bottle I have had of the 3 this year, smoother than normal.

Bottle, 75 cl, 2007 vintage, ABV 6 pct: Deep orange beer with a foamy, but quickly diminishing white head. Aroma is citric with some nice malty notes and hints of flowers and wood. Taste has some horseblanket, but also malty, flowery and bitter hoppy fruity notes of orange peel. Mouthfeel is tart, subdued brett, light malty sweet, yet dry and hoppy bitter in the finish. Refreshing.

75 cL bottle from Beers of Europe into a Hoegaarden Speciale glass.  Effervescent when poured.  Dark orange and fizzy.  Nice sweet/sour aorma, not too much.  Bitter but palatable.  Dry with hints of fruit.  Pleasant but as spectacular as hoped.
Bottle of 75 cl. vintage the 2003rd Sweet and tart flavor of vinegar and fruit. Sour taste of vinegar, courtyard and ground

Bottle. 2005 vintage enjoyed in 2012. Hazy, amber liquid with medium, white head. Aroma of citrus, lemons, apples, funk, barnyard and wheat. Taste is dry, medium sour and not bitter. Light medium bodied with good carbonation. Really nice lambic

Mycket trevlig Cantillon-doft av ekfat, blommor och äpplen.
Torr vätska, fin syrlighet, fläder, frukt - en lite lagom cantillon ingen extrem

Had this at Cafe Brocante, Brussels, Belgium 17.12.11   Ive had this on a few occasions before but for some reason Ive never got around to rating this. Pours light amber, touch hazy with a light beige head. Dry and funky, fruity and sour. This is one tasty beer, I love the dryness, there is dustiness, mmmhh.. cracking stuff.   A7 A4 T8 P4 Ov15  3.8

1 pint, 9.4 fl oz bottle. A solid lambic here with a funky, mild, balanced profile. Pours with a deep woody orange body, and pilowy, thick, starch white head. Funk and mixed buttery cereal grains are prominent in the nose. Some tart berries, simple tart citrus, cheesy wood, and nutty granola bar as well in this interesting aroma. Bitterness in the palate in stronger than expected, mixed with a funky tartness. Medium bodied with mellow carbonation as well. The flavor notes are not a diverse as the nose, but decent never-the-less. Mixed buttery grains, sour herbs, tart mixed fruits of mainly citrus and dates. Funk and herbal prominent in the finish. Overall, this was very likable.

750ml bottle @ Gloria, Kuopio
2006 vintage - Pours dark orange with a tiny bubbly white head. Armoa is fruity with notes of berries and sour notes. Taste is quite fruity and sour with notes of berries, spices and dry malts. Finish is dry and sour with berry notes. Nice, well balanced fruity lambic.
2005 bottle.  Pours a hazy orange with almost no head.  Aroma of sour fruits, dust and barnyard.  Taste is tart citrus, yeast, apples, wood and some hops.  Dry finish.  Unique.  Unique.

16-12-11 Bouteille 375ml 2007: Belle apparence orangée légèrement trouble avec une petite effervescence et un petit collet de mousse blanche persistante. Arômes très funky style barnyard, avec un touche moyenne dacidité et de fruits. Légèrement sucrée et complexe en saveurs, avec du fruits, de lacidité, une légère amertume. Bien balancé, même si asser funky. Pourrait facilement boire cette bière assis sur une botte de foin dans une grange! Très plaisante à boire, mais avec modération, car elle pourrait finir par taper sur le coeur

UPDATED: APR 27, 2014 My first ever unblended lambic!
Appearance: Light amber. Clear, but some sediments left in the bottle. Shortlived, fizzy off-white head.
Aroma: Sour. Wet wood. Some fruits hiding behind the sourness as well.
Taste: What is happening to me? This is the first gueuze/lambic that I dont find revolting. More of the same sourness, but less than other lambics. Ever so slight fruits. Sour aftertaste, but not too bad.
Info: 750ml bottle, 16/12-2011, 44/100, 40/300M

Served on-tap at Maxs Taphouse during their "Rare and Obscure" event.
A - Pours amber yellow with a small one finger tall white head leaving spotty lacing down the glass.
S - Smells of strong barn yard funk, light acidic sourness, and some white grape skin. Not as strong a nose as I was expecting.
T - Holy pucker batman. Lots of strong puckering sourness up front slowly giving way to a mix of green apples, grapes, and light brett funk. The alcohol is well hidden behind all that sourness. The finish is pretty dry, lingering for some time. More sourness than I was initially expecting.
M - Medium body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Strong, acidic, feel with a good bit of dryness in the finish.
O - I liked this one, just not as much as the other two. It was, surprisingly to me at least, the most sour of the three. I tend to like my sours with a bit more fruit in them but this was still very nice.

11 Bottle. Pours a hazy golden orange color with a white head. Aroma is of white grape, oak, vinegar, green apple, funk like barnyard, musty old cellar aromas and smells really sour. The flavor is super sour with lots of citrus and vinegar, I get white grape, oak, green apple, funk in the way of horseblanket and barnyard along with musty old flavors. The body is light with a dry mouthfeel. Overall a really tasty and extremely sour Unblended Lambic.

Light golden amber with a off-white head which stays. I smell berries and specially rowanberries, and sour apple. This also present in the flavours, and vinegar. Tangy bitterness, and dry in the end. Medium to heavy carbo and feels crisp in the mouth. A very fresh and delightful lambic. I hope got the opportunity to taste this again.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 Hazy orange with light bubbly head. Sourness, plums, wheat. Astringent sourness but totally refined and delicious. Warming and with great aftertaste. One of the best geuzes ive had. (Rating re-indexed)

2007 vintage bottled in 2010 as indicated by the cork.  Pours pale amber with lush dense rocky head, great retention and slight haze.  Aroma is very floral hoppy grapefruit, refined barnyard funk, lemon tartness, french oak mustiness, vinuous, melon?  Taste is super sour with grapefruit, hints of musty cowhide, lemon, lime, gets even funkier as it warms.  Body is light, effervescent, highly acidic, cowhide grapefruit lime finish.  Overall, a great if unrefined lambic that actually exhibits some well-balanced hop bitterness!!

0.75l bottle - the 2007 version from Ølbutikken shared with The Tasting Crew + friends. This one pours a lovely looking clouded fairy tale orange body with a nice big and light fluffy lasting just off-white head. Nice aromas. Its light and mildly tart and woody, but also light red-fruity, apricots, sour apples and cowberries. Average carbonation levels and a kinda fading oily mouthfeel. Tastes light sour apples, light sour lemons, more pungent and bitter - and definitely not to sour. Really nice stuff!

37.5 cL bottle (2003) at Home in 2009. I didint expect to like it because I am not at all familair with geuzes. However it was quite interesting. Dry, sour, cheesy notes, the famous horse blanket, wet wood, a nice touch of hops. I will ahve to rerate it when I am more used to the style though.

Bottle from 2003. pours  hazy light orange/ amber with fluffy white head, Aroma:  dusty, lactoacid, brett, lemon, floral, dandelion, plant like, farty, light sulfur, cheese, light vinegar, medium mouthfeel, taste is lemon, light vinegar, some dusty hop bitterness, lemon peel, green apples, dusty, refreshing, high drinkability, apricot, quite dry, nice!

Hazy apricot in color with a micron of white head.  Aroma is sour like a kombucha made with apple juice.  Taste is extremely sour, with bright acetic notes, tamed by a bit of bitterness, which trails off into a bretty afterfunk.  6Eu at the brewery

2003 Vintage Bottle from Ölbuttiken, at home. 5th November, 2011.

Pours golden amber with a light fading head. Sweet and sourish aromas of apple and flowers - pretty funky and fresh for being so old. No oxidation what so ever. Fresh and light taste, flowery with a mild acidity, not very sour compared to other Cantillons. Barnyard notes is of course mixed in as well. What strikes me the most is the bitterness of the beer. Its considerably higher then what Im used to. Nevertheless a great beer that have stood the test of time!

Bouteille @ Cantillon.
Orangée brumeuse, col blanc.
Bière fascinante avec une tournure originale du dry-hopping venant du Saaz. Le tout garde ce profile vinaigre tout en restant sèche avec la levure donnant un profile de cave cela se mélangeant parfaitement avec ce houblon laissant transparaitre des épices. On retrouve des notes boisées et de grains.

750 ml bottle a dark golden yellow orange colored beer with a white head aroma sourness apples earthy spicy citrus and some hops flavor sourness apple earthy spicy citrus pineapple lemon and some hop bitters in de finish

Bottle @ Yngwies, courtesy of Yngwie. Thanks man! :-) Slightly hazy orange body, virtually no head. Nose is bretty funk tones, lemon, sweat, floral tones and hints of grapes, sour socks (but in a good way!) and raw straw. Intense and nice. Taste is sweat, lemon, stale barnyard funk, hints of metal, straw and dry, grassy hops. Intense, well-rounded (probably due to the age) and very nice.
Pours a golden amber colour with a thick off white head that clings to the edges of the glass. The aroma is oak vanilla little sour notes. Taste is crispy sweet  almost like a sour apple juice.

flat looking, golden fluid.  pale haze laced throughout.  nose of rotting wood, vinegary grains, slight yeast, and interesting floral characters.  complex to say the least.  taste was very hard to rasp cue to the flatness of the beer.  not sure if it was supposed to be that way, but it was not enjoyable on the mouth, and tended to disable the flavors, but I caught musty earthy hops that tasted dead in the bottle, some light sourness that came across very astringent and full of tannins, puckering, pickled-type flavors happening.  unique, but not my favorite.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2012 In bottle at The BrewDog Bar, Edinburgh. Pours a cloudy golden colour with a lacy white head. A lovely aroma of lemon, horse blanket, barley, hay, wet cardboard and a very light balsamic vinegar tang. Similar flavours, quite tart with lemon and a mild dry balsamic vinegar quality again. Barley and hay characters also. A tart finish and linger. Mild carbonation and CO2 prickle. Very nice. 2005 bottle, thanks Craig. Lovely musty aroma, mild balsamic vinegar although this has settled nicely. Similar flavours with dry Granny Smith apple skin also. Lovely!

Bottle. This Was pretty wild. Even for a lambic. the sourness,  and bitterness were impressive. Unbelievable acidity on the tongue and on the inside of my neck as it went down. This beer provokes a grimace but is in fact - excellent. The hops are present but in a different way to an IPA. A challenging and rewarding bottle.
Typical gueuze aroma though perhaps a little more grainy. Fantastic flavour. Dominant sourness.
from bottle. Pours orange, no head. Very nice lambic aroma and taste with a hoppy afterthought. Very acidic

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours a cloudy rich orange with virtually no head. Aroma of cider vinegar, funk, sour fruits. Flavour of cider, sour fruits, funk, banana, Well balanced, nicely carbonated. Really good.
Bottle 2007 at rattle n hum.   Sour and rich... Some florals and dustiness.  Delicious.

Bottled (1 pint 9.4 fl oz) at RnH w James, Andy, Streets. Light orange pour with some hazy orange hue. Medium white head. Aroma is vinegar, citrus and soapiness; palate is apple cider vinegar, some dry fruit (pears?) and a little wateriness with not much of an aftertaste at all. Tart and sour, but not to the max. Good.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2013 
75 cl bottle (6%) @ home. Bottled on 26.01.2011, BBE 12/2015
Sourish and somewhat tart aroma has lots of earthy notes and some tart, Finnish green apple. Flavour is really sour and tart with gastric acid and some malt. Very dry finish, the palate becomes a bit sticky towards the end of the glass. Rather unique and good lambic.

an interesting beer that I enjoyed more than I expected. The hops a there but they are over powering. more tart than sour (which I find to be a plus). Not something I would really seek out again but I can appreciate the quality behind the product.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2011 What a great product from Cantillon this is. Alot more bitterness, with less sourness. For a geuze - ipa lover, this is a must to drink bottle. Compared two ages; 2011 vs 2005, a really interesting experience.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2012 (750ml corked 2011). In a Cantillon tulip . This was a bit of a gem really.  Not being sure what to expect with a Lambic made with fresh and stale hops - all the beautiful Cantillon horseblanket shit does its service and you get the awesome unity between chessey pungent stale hoppiness and fresh floral hops , ive ever had such a marriage .   Really a drinkable and classy  beer , ilike anything Cantillon.. A nice concept.
From the bottle. Poured a dull orange with a foamy white head. Smells sour and tart, some funky earthy notes with apple and vinegar. The flavor is exceedingly sour with grapefruit at the end.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2016 Tap @ Akkurat.
Hazy brownish orange with a short short lived lively yellowed head.
Aroma: Fermented sour apples, horseblanket, pickled cucumber.
Taste: very sour with pickled vegetables, apples, grapefruit, pips and a soft note of caramel in the aftertaste.
Medium body with small pointy bubbles.

2007 on draft.  Sampled at the Churchkey on Zwanze day 2011.  Orange pour with a white head.  Aroma was aggressively sour and funky.  Some malt hiding in the background maybe?  Some fruit notes but the first sip of this thing was like a punch in the face.  Very sour in a good way.  Took a few sips to get past the sourness but the rest was rewarding.  Tasty beer if a bit one note.

2007 Draft. Poured a slightly dark yellow/orange color - almost like apple cider. Aroma is earthy, very tart and sour notes come through. Flavor is, well, very disappointing. I dont know - a lot of people seemed to really like it at Zwanze Day 2011 (Id hate to think it but being $6 for a 4oz pour may have forced them to like it). My friend likened it to something along the lines of fermented dirt. I thought the flavor was a bit astringent, and the palate was not pleasing in the least. Since this was my first beverage of the day (aside from water), my palate was entirely clean.

Bottle from The Cracked Kettle web shop. Hazy orange golden color with medium light yellow fast dissapearing head. Aroma of lemon, hops, cheese, toasted grain, wood, floral notes. Taste, heavily acidic, with some sweet hints. Nice grapefruit bitter hops finish. My first Lambic Unblended, nice beer.
5.5 oz pour at Beachwood Sour Fest.   Poured dark gold with no head.  Aroma of jasmine.  Intense sour taste.
Clear, deep orange colour. Smells sour, cellar, wood and earth. Tastes sour, acidic and apple. Very long after, good carbo.

Courtesy of Jason Bertrand, who cant remember his Ratebeer name, but is a great friend nonetheless. Aroma of slight caramel, white grape, tart lemon and maybe just a bit of leather. Appearance is honey gold with light white head. Flavor has a reasonable amount of tartness with medium acidity, the lemon really shines through. Palate is lightly bubbly and thin. A good place to start for my first unblended Lambic.

2004 bottle...pours a murky honey color with a medium creamy white head.  Aroma has leather and funk...slightly musty...faint hint of soury notes.  Flavor is more sour than the aroma suggests but not aggressive...still carries nice funk/musty notes as well...very tart and lemony...refreshing.  Mouthfeel is very light and silky with a tart dry finish.

Bottle 750ml vintage 2003 courtesy of meilby. Pours hazy orange with white fluffy head. Aroma is basement, earth, vinegar, sour on the nose. Taste is very sour for a short while. Light body, thin, high carbonation.  20110421

En 2003:a, 8 år gammal med andra ord. Simmig orangegul vätska som inte skummar alls. Typiskt syrlig doft av syrliga äpplen, ek och stall. Förvånansvärt snäll syra. Smaken är elegant med en inledande söt-torr syrlighet. Fina toner av färsk/våt humle, lite honung och mineraler. Mjuk syrlighet med en viss beska. De mjuka mineralrika smakerna återkommer i den syrliga eftersmaken som har toner av honungsmelon som klingar av i en behaglig syrlighet.
 gör den väldigt drickvänlig.
color naranja cobrizo,acida con final amargo.Se nota mas el lúpulo que otras lambicas.Muy buena.

(2007 Vintage) Hazy amber/orange color; Medium body; Aroma of yeast, rich sour fruit, floral, & citrus; Flavor of malt/yeast, oak, sour fruit (notably apples & grapes), citrus (notably lemon & grapefruit), hops, and some vinegar; Finish is dry and quite sour; Nicely balanced and complex; Overall, has the standard barnyard funk - but this was pretty good.

Pours hazy and deep orange with a rather nice head. Aroma is tart, lemony, some sweetness and apricot. Slightly hoppy (dont know how old the bottle was, but think if you have a fresh bottle the hops will be more pronounced) and very subtle. Very well balanced beer, medium bodied and not so rough like some other Cantillon products. Like the added hops and didnt expect it to be so mellow, although you definitely know you are having a lambic.
Bottle @ home shared withDutchDrebus. Clear dark orange / copper colored, almost no head. Smell sour, not much more. Taste sour, dry, and acidic in the finish. Average carbo and body.
shared by someone at about 9 in the morning on the day of hunahpu release.  poured an amber color with a white head.  aroma and flavor were lemon and sharp acidity.  body was light and refreshing.

A bottle from a friend who sells this beer.  Unique sour brew (maybe the cold hopping, I dont know). Bitter at the beginning, hints of some type of citrus, people said lemon taste, maybe, and then sour finish.  Well balanced and complexity going on with this brew.

750 mL bottle corked.  2007 Vintage.  Poured amber with medium white head and fine lacing.  Aroma of floral hops and citrus.  Tastes of hops and slightly sour, a nicely balanced beer with good mouthfeel, nice carbonation and good body.  Really enjoyable.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2012 Shared bottle at BrewDog Edinburgh. Hazy dark amber, little white head. Earthy sour nose, funky lemon, orange peel. Sherbet sour palate with a hint of grain, some oakiness, light fruit (mandarin?). Tart finish. 7 3 7 4 18
28/01/12 - 2005 Vintage courtesy of cgarvieuk. Wow.  Real orange golden colour, no head. Amazing complex nose, sour orange candy, slightly rye, leathery, lack of balsamic adds real depth. Soft dry front, sharp apple skins, amazingly complex, big but well-integrated sourness, leather definitely there, soft, woody, slightly honey finish. Incredibly special. 9 4 8 4 19

Bouquet:  Earthy, floral and grassy hops, perfumed, white grapefruit, spicey, peppery, dried apricot, orange.

Flavor: White pepper, apricot, hint of nutmeg?, straw, yeast, white grapefruit  plus sour and bitter rind flavors.

Comment:  More rounded than the framboise and kriek, though the finish is less intense.

2007 bottle shared by a few kind folks. Pours a light golden orange with a small white head. Aroma of nice sharp funky barnyard notes, some light zesty lemon peel, lightly vinegar and a touch herbal. Flavor is even funkier, lots of barnyard and sharp lemon zest and lemon grass. Beautiful sharp vinegar and dry woodiness. Finishes sharp and biting. Medium body and a soft carbonation (itd been out for awhile). Amazing stuff

Bottle. 2003 vintage. Pours cloudy deep golden colored with a small lasting egg white head. Aromas of spice, brett, vinegar, honey and basement. Sour and spicy flavor with a dry, tart and long finish. Awesome!

Hazy golden color with a small white bubble head. Wonderful sour notes, lemongrass and that fantastic barnyard. Flavor is a touch lemony, with apples and a touch of wood. Nice carbonation and drying finish.

Bottle. Aroma is green apple, hay, barnyard, brett and some belgian hops.
Flavour is intense and extreme sourness. Loads of green apple and some hay. Intense. A bit too sour to taste a lot else.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2013 Bottle 75 cl at Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Poured cloudy dark orange in colour with thin off-white head. Sour vinegar and sour apple in aroma. Quite dry. Not as much sour apple in flavour but more vinegary notes in taste. Nonetheless quite tasty. Good sour ale. 8-3-8-3-15.

Re-rate 2013
Draught. Pours amber in color with a small head. Sour notes, bit of stable and vinegar in aroma. Tart mouthfeel. Some fresh apples and vinegary notes in taste. Bit of fruity elements linger underneath. Sour apples in aftertaste.
8-3-4-8-16

75cl bottle @Pikkulintu. Labeled Iris 2007. Poured hazy orange with a thin head.  Barnyard, sour aroma, very nice indeed.  Quite high carbonation. Acidic flavor, apples and some woody notes as well. Long lingering finish. Very interesting and tasty beer.

Tap at Stone Sour Fest 2011. Pours a hazy yellow with a nice frothy head.  Tons of citrus in the aroma with some nice sourness picked up but very little funk. The bitter lemon peel really hits you when you first sip this beer.  This stays to the end but is not over powering and is a very nice sour beer.  Not overly mouth puckering but a very enjoyable beer.  Wish I could taste more of the "cold hopping" but cant in this taste.  Overall a very enjoyable beer and one that I could drink on any summer evening.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text:
Appearance:  Pours an amber tinted gold with a thin eggshell colored head.

Aroma: Musky funk, slight mildew and sourness.

Taste: Mineral or metallic like bitterness, wood tannin notes, lacto.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied, light fizz.

Overall:  A very complex beer, not very sour. There is a lot going on in this beer, but it all falls into place with each sip.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2014 Bottle. Pours hazy orange with a white head. Aroma is tart with notes of bread crust, horse, citrus, wood, floral, fainted hops, yeast, light caramel and grapefruit. Taste is tart with notes og lemon peel, fainted hops, grapefruit, green apples, floral, brett and stable.  Dry mouthfeel .. Really good indeed!

Draught at Maxs Rare and Obscure.  Pour was cloudy orange with a white head.  Aromas were sour, yeasty, and funky.  Taste was sour on the front, with lots of fruit.  The finish provided a nice balance with the hops that kick in.  Overall, a very well done beer, very refreshing.
This is a world class beer. Sampled at Stone Sourfest 11. Sour like a sour patch kid. Pours a hazy orange. Slightly bitter with big grapefruit notes at the end.

2000 at Ungstrups - Thanks. Pours a clear light amber with a small off-white head and lacings. Smells of sour dust. Sour and quite bitter. Fruity aromas with aromas of cask. Quite dry. Weird aromas of old hops. Medium to full bodied. Soft carbonation. Dry, casky carboantion.

Dezent säuerlicher Antrunk, deutlich herb, was von der Holzigkeit zu kommen scheint. In Teilen essigähnlich, diese Säuerlichkeit nimmt im Mittelteil bereits wieder ab, bleibt aber dennoch deutlich vorhanden. Dieser etwas merkwürige Ton scheint mit der Zeit süßer und bekömmlicher zu werden, man brauch tatsächlich erst einmal Eingewöhnungszeit. Kein Bier für Jedermann! 	 
Test vom 22.12.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 9,12,10,11,11,12 - 11,20

Bottle bought from the brewery and shared with friends.  Pours slightly hazy golden with no head.  Aroma is sour fruity brett.  Lots of grapefruit in the flavor.  Almost no carbonation.  Very good beer, but certainly not one of the best Cantillons

75cl bottle shared with Kermis and another friend.  Thanks Kermis!
No head/carbonation.  Hazy deep golden colour.  Sour aftertaste.  Im new to geuzes.  I will have to re-rate this later

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2014 (28/05/2011) 2010 Vintage [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ 2011: hazy yellow with a very lasting white head, smells like sour with wet hops & yeast, taste is sour with wheat, barnyard funk, yeast, brett, horse blanket, tart hop, medium body but bit heavier than other Cantillons, medium carbonation, amazing beer///// 2007 Vintage [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, sampled, similar taste only it seems to have gotten a lot stronger and less subtle, way more in your face in everyway, more tart than sour now, both version are excellent /////////////// Additional notes. Many more samples. 2014 very fresh one @ brewery it seems super hoppy. Couple of days later tried a +/- 6 months or so old bottle, very interest, quite full body, great body, hop flower, malty body, almost sugar. Might rate this one higher at some point.

some quickly dissapearing head, dark golden in colour
Sour nose with citrus, honey, red lollipop, lightweight
Medium body and very fine length
Taste of grapefruits, limonad, hops? sour
Pretty fruity and delicious

Bouteille de 750ml. Bière cuivrée-orangée avec une mousse blanche très durable. Le nez est bien agréable avec des arômes de houblons à saveurs dagrumes et de levure sauvage. La bouche est agréable, lamertume en finale est bien marqué, les goûts de pamplemousse provenant des houblons du houblonnage à froid sont prononcés. Franchement une très bonne bière.

(75 cl, vintage 2007)  Le liquide a une robe orangée qui demeure embrouillée.  La tête mousseuse demblée épaisse disparaît en un clin dil.  Au nez, des parfums de levure spontanée se frottent à des effluves de barrique et à des fruits légèrement coupants.  Au fil de la dégustation, des arômes de fleurs semblent se détacher.  Les saveurs sont très belles, justement aigres, parfaitement acidulées, légèrement grimaçantes,  bien asséchantes: une explosion de notes surettes et boisées attaquées par de bons microbes belges.  Trop facile à boire.  En bouche, le liquide a un corps moyen qui est traversé par des bulles fines et vitaminées.  La finale se fait sur des notes vives qui se combinent à une amertume presque fantomatique.  Un délice.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy light bronze with a rocky cream coloured head. Huge funky aromas with some acidity, Light floral and citrus aromas which I guess are coming from the hops. Flavours show great acidity and plenty of the funk. Some hops on the finish.Not my favourite Cantillon but still a bloody great beer.

Bottle 375ml vintage 2003 @ Zoney
Pours hazy orange with a white head. Aroma is the typical cantillon aroma with notes of vinegar. Taste is heavy sour with a very dry finish. Body is medium, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

2007 vintage generously shared by Huhzubendah to help me finish off both the top Belgian list and the top Unblended Lambic list. Served in a tulip.

Pours copper with a very, very large off-white head with really good retention. The nose is pretty interesting with some slight funk and a few floral notes. Theres a bit of acidity there as well. Mild earth. The taste takes this to the next level. There is a light acidic presence with some notes of light stone fruits plus some damp earth and general musk. Body is fairly light and low in carbonation. Finish is tart, yet not too bracing. Quite drinkable. Thanks again, Matt!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-14-2011
Bottle at home shared with mom and dad. Nice sour notes, dry wood flavors - lingers nicely. Great sour.

375ml bottle, 2007 vintage bottled 21/01/10. An effervescent, slightly unclear ruddy amber coloured beer with a tall & rocky, slowly disappearing off-white to beige head that leaves a loose, soapy lacing. Tangy green apples, lemon & white wine on the aroma with an underlying orange sweetness & a bit of grapefruit is that? Green apples & pithy orange with a puckering dryness and a modest green hop, grapefruit bitterness. Light to medium body, fairly lively mouthfeel with a lingering dryness and bitter finish. Leaves a good dose of orange in the aftertaste.

Bottle at the Rake enjoyed with big wallopper MagicDave6. It pours amber with moderate carbonation and a very thin yellow-white head. The nose is sour, hay, floral, grass and wood. The taste is lemon-sherbet, acidic Granny Smith apple, floral, grass, hay, surprising bitterness and wood with a satisfyingly long tart-bitter finish. There is a great balance between sweet, sour and bitter.

2004 vintage thanks to my boy Greg in NYC... a dark gold almost copper body, murky, decent bright white head... the aroma is awesome, tons of malted grains, musky funk barnyard, great flavors wonderfully restrained though... interesting sweet malts on the front with very sour horse blanket lactic sour, tastes great... mouthfeel is great, makes me pucker, totally coating and full... 7 years old but damn good, would like to try one just slightly newer to see how they are fresh

37,5cl bottle vintage 2005
Cloudy orange/golden color with a slight head that can become quite big for a geuze when you pour vigorously. The aroma is quite musty with notes of flowery hops. The flavor starts very sour and gives you all the characteristic dusty musty flavors you expect from a geuze and ends in a dry aftertaste with a citrus, aged hop aftertaste. An interesting and refreshing geuze.

2007 vintage. Beer served in a snifter. Beer is dark amber and completely hazy. Forms a surprisingly big head (the cork really popped out fast) and the carbonation is really high. Head is off white and made up of small bubbles. Doesnt leave much lacing on the glass. Looks great (although I dont mind my unblended lambics to have almost no carbonation).

Strongly tart with mild fruit aromas in the nose. Apples, some apricots (I know these fruits arent here, just saying what I can smell). Mild acetic acid notes, nice lactic notes. Smells good.

Beer is super sour and has a nice funk to it. Lots of carbonation in the mouth. This pushes the limits of what I think a sour can be. Very lactic / citric in the front and then oak and woodsy at the back with a lingering funk. Drinkability is good but its not my favorite lambic from them. Overall I still thoroughly enjoyed it.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle @ home. Hazy dark red-orange appearance with a big orange cream colored head. Acidic, sour, wild, light citrus fruity, lightly floral Belgian lambic nose. Wild, sweet citrusy, lightly floral, barnyard, musty, and quite sour flavor. Sour, aged lambic flavor gets especially potent at the back of the tongue. This is my first unblended lambic rating, so Im a beginner to this style but overall it has a potent sour flavor and a little more rough than blended lambics. 2007 vintage.

Bottle, 2005 vintage - Pours clear amber with a huge foamy white head. Funky tart sulfur nose, with lemon, dry floral notes, and some sweet citrus. Taste is tart citrus peel, dry with a bit of stale hop flavor. Nice tartness and pretty acidic, but overall still very easy to drink. Softly carbonated and smooth. The only weird thing about this beer was the black moldy-looking stuff that was all over the cork when we took the cap off. It didnt smell moldy, and it wiped off, but I couldnt help but think that drinking this beer was going to give me some horrible disease. Thankfully it didnt...yay Cantillon!

Taster at Hunaphus release. This was a very light in color, light in body beer. The aroma was a tad fruity with hints of apples. The flavor was a little tart and dry. Not the best of the day but a pretty good one.
UPDATED: FEB 2, 2013 Vintage 2003. Hazy orange with a white head. Aroma is malty, wood, notes of fruit and barnyard. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate acidic. Dry and moderate acidic finish. 160311

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2013 7 Sept 2013, tap. pinkish orange and a tad hazy. nose is cobwebs and sour orange rind. med body, dry and lildly fizzy. cobwebs and dry oak. very dry, not very sour. cereal malt present but oaky sour is prominent. 
(original rating 7 3 7 3 12 = 3.2) Mar 15, 2011, bottle. yellow orange colour. white grapefruit aroma and very tart smell. doesnt smell as tart as other cantillons. thin/med body and faintly fizzy. very dry and puckers the mouth. soft and mildly sweet, at least in contrast to the tartness.
i like this. it has certain wine/champagne characteristics but also some fun lambic elements. very good.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2012 10 bottle.  Initially thick and bubbly head fading to a thin slick of foam with steady carbonation.  Beer is light red/pink in color and clear.  Aroma is clean and light tart, wheat-like malt, and subtle background sour/tart and funk.  Taste is tart up front with lemon gueuze through the middle followed by light malt before a sour/tart finish.  Dry, precise feel in the mouth.  I really like this beer - wonderful.=====================11 bottle.  Hazy copper color with a froth of white foam.  Aroma is dry wheat, sour with a bit of tart, a dusting of earthy hops, lemon, and a bit of underlying funk.  Taste is tart with cheese rind funk, lemon, wheat, and a bit more sour into the finish.  Clean and dry.  Excellent.  Wouldnt change anything about the numbers on the rating.

Bottle (thx for sharing tarheels!). Pours a hazy yellow/orange with a gigantic white head which takes minutes to settle. Aroma is intense barnyard funk, lemon, grassy/floral hops, citrus. Flavor is funky and hoppy, very smooth rounded palate; easy to drink. Really hard beer not to love and would make a very sessionable beer (for me) if not for the pricetag.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2011 375ml bottle. Pours a  cloudy orangish/brownish color with a big bubbly white head. Aroma is mostly sweet-sour with oak and horse blanket qualities. Taste is sweet/sour, almost lemon peel. Grassy earthy notes. Some bittering hops. Very nice. Medium bodied and lots of carbonation.

Sidenote: 6% ABV on the back label.

2007 Bottle.  Light orange pour, plenty of lasting carbonation and an aroma of sour stomach acid(but in a good way.)  Flavor is very sour grapefruit, acid, some hop bitterness and a lasting funky aftertastes.  Really liked this one, and very doable at $20/bottle.

head: white, creamy 
colour: deep amber 
smell: malts allready !!, grassy, bitter/sour, hops, lemon and something that reminds me of "la paz" cigars ?! 
taste: very sour start, malts, champagny appeal but only more sour, despite of in a regular geueze that meets a bit of wa grape/ green apple like appeal , this one clearly runs over into hops with a clearly grassy taste , overall texture is dryer than a regular geueze , theres more to say but i think i might be overgo it so ill end my case here ... a great lambic !!

i really need to get me some more canillon stuff ...

750 mL bottle, 2007 vintage, bottled in 2010.  Pours hazy golden orange with a slightly off-white head.  Citric sour aroma with bits of red apple, honey, funk.  Flavor is more of lactic acid, with citric acid flavor backing it up, apple, citrus fruitiness.  A little chalkiness, grassy flavor, and a small bitter bite as it finishes.  Pretty tasty beer.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2012 1996 Bottle at Monks for the Cellar Dinner. First of the night, and first batch ever brewed of this beer.  Poured pinkish copper, no lacing or head. Aromas of sour gueuze, tons of wood, lemon, barn, apricots, funk, peach, lactic notes. Taste is unbelievably soft, perfectly cellared for the 16 years, lemon woods, peach, mouth watering sour ale. Aamzing. 2007 bottle Pours a hazy, murky turbid orange with a thin, white, creamy head. Shiny, reflective surface. Aroma of barnyard funk, sharp cheese, lemon zest, lavender, blueberry, dry hops, wild yeasts, grass, and earth. Full bodied with a smooth, creamy, roundly robust, tart palate. Notes of sharp, savory cheese in the finish. Bit sour too. The age on this brew really balanced it nicely and gave the sour a solid, malty, floral backbone. Excellent lambic.
hazy orange coloured body with a little white head a spicy yeasty sour fruity aroma a sour fruity spicy herby bitter taste with a sour bitter finish

From notes:

2005 vintage. Pours a dark hazy amber/orange color with a one finger frothy white head that quickly settles into a thin ring. Minimal spots of lacing. Visible carbonation bubbling up.

Funky aroma with a decent amount of barnyard/horseblanket character as well as hints of earthy oak, tannins, vinegar, light fruit and earthy hops.

Medium bodied and puckering without being acidic at all. Sour/tart up front with a decent balance of musty/earthy oak along with subtle pale malt, earthy, bitter hops and crisp light fruit. Very complex and well balanced with a nice amount of citrus and other sweet, vinous fruits balancing out the sour funk. In addition, the hops used make this beer very unique for the style. The dry and cold hopping results in a earthier, slightly more bitter lambic than usual, but not to the detriment of the other characteristics. Theres still plenty of funk but this is slightly better balanced and easier to drink than some other Belgian sours. Recommended.
Light amber orange coloured beer with small white head and only few carbonation. Sour herby aroma. Full sour palate bit sparkling. Finish is sour ending bitter sour. Pour one. (@WE - 14/01/11)

Cloudy dark orange pour, quickly disappearing white head. Aroma of blue cheese, barnyard and more brett related aromas. Flavor is very sour, some earth and a hint of bitterness. Very lively carbonation. Bubbly texture. Quite overwhelming sourness but still a nice brew.

Pours an amber peach color with a nice head. Smells like barnyard, sour peaches, hops. The taste is more of the same, the sour is amazingly crisp and refreshing. I have had this beer at least 10x, how have I not rated this? Awesome.

On tap at Ma Che Siete Venuti a Fà. Very few frothy. Hazy and amber body. Some metal feeling during tasting, not too much aggressive. The citrus is more noticeable in the finish and it is dry enough. Good!

750 ml bottle of 2005 vintage from Bieropholie, shared with Phil, served cool in a Pils flute. Bottled 23MR07. 01JA11. 
App.:  Cloudy orange-amber with a small off-white head.
  
Aroma:  A mix of leafy hops and Lambic funk, some citrus notes, strong peppery herbals, typical horse blanket and barnyard, leather, a bit of rubber, strong sourness.
  
Palate:  Medium body and fair effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Strong, bracing acidity, bitter green herbs, funk, lots of minerals, some faint fruit notes, peppery, typical Lambic notes; SO sour with some bitterness, tangy fruit and minerals.

Still not a fan!!
Bottle. Pours red grapefruit color. Nose of fresh peach, tart fruit, oak, flowers and barrel funk. Taste is acidic fruit, grapefruit rind and oaks.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2011 37,5 cl bottle (vintage 2003), pours orange with a minor head, aroma is fairly tart consisting of brett, barnyard, fruit and wood, taste is similar to the nose, pretty sour but not unpleasant in any way, super smooth mouthfeel, lovely beer.

Pours hazy peach amber a small beige head. Aroma is very sweet and fruity but also tart and sour. Very nice. Flavor is acidy sour and a bit tart with nice fruity tones. Palate is sour. Finishes sour acidy and tart with some fruity notes left in my mouth. Very nice lambic.

Bottle from bierkompass.de . fresh bottle: feb 2010 bb 2020-02
cons Götteborg 2010-12-20
AR: fresh geuze, yeast, young apples, nutty
FP: reddish copper colored body, wee yellowis beige head wee bubble and quickly diminishing
F: small bubbly carbonation, heavy bitterness, appel tart, yeast, loaded with souness, grapefruit, rhubarb and rowanberry fruitiness

This was for a 1998 version. The aging REALLY helped this beer. Honeydew, strawberries, peaches, a touch of lemon and cherries and hay. Oaky lemon fresh cut flowers, dandelions,  moderately tart, wood , earth. Unbelievably delicate,  but delicious.

2007 Vintage.  I picked this up a while ago at West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago, IL and saved it for a good time.  Just got good job news, my band finished our full length record, life is good!  This was drunk out of a coffee mug during the final record mixing so its a bit skewed.  Appearance caramel gold with rich white head.  Aroma of cheese and Belgian yeast, very soft.  Taste not as sour as I was anticipating, definitely unique, pretty good.

Bottle from Beer Ritz, Leeds. Wasnt prepared for just how pant wettingly good this is. Hazy orange pour with a lingering white rim. Terrific aroma, a wonderful mix of full on lemon citrus, hops and a dash of funk. The flavour was just wonderful, a sublime and perfectly balanced mix of lip puckering sourness and hop bitterness. Every sip was just a joy. A sensational beer that I could drink till the bloody cows come home.

Cold-hopped unblended lambic?? Yes please. 750ml bottle- 2007 vintage. When I prised the cap, beer started foaming through the cork- quite an entrance, and not the kind of hissing carbonation Ive come to expect from lambic. Pours clear to dusky honey-amber with a subsiding, uneven, slightly yellowed collar. Intense, drool-making scent of mouldy lemon, horseblanket,  blackcurrant wine gums. Not as bone dry and teeth-squeakingly caustic as your typical Cantillon; plenty of lemon and sour apple acidity, but leavened with honey, green tea and Rowntrees blackcurrant wine gum notes. I really can taste a citric, lemon zest softness from the hops here- deep in the mix, but reminiscent of a US variety (!). Goes from puckeringly tart to hoppily (almost) dry in one swig. Complex, approachable. Not overpowered by stomach-rotting acidity. Uncommonly good beer, and probably my favourite Cantillon Ive had to date.

Bought at the brewery and I had this at home here in Sweden. It was definitely worth the money. Pours a beautiful orange and little cloudy. Aroma is just fantastic. Complex. Has fruits, citrus, cops, barn and is vinous. Flavor is fruity, acid, vinous and bitter. Palate is dry and just fantastic.

Dark orange and hazy. Big, frothy, off white head. As I pour it into the glass the air is filled with the smell of acid. Very sour and full with acidity. After a while I am rather sure that it is lemon that I am tasting. There is a presence of pine too. Aroma is mostly lemon, acid and yeast. This is a rather special drink.

2006 bottle at Where the Wild Beers Are. Murky bronze pour with eggshell head. Oak and oats in the nose that are topped by a great cheesy funkiness and some lemon peel. Flavor is rich of lemon undercut by horseblanket and some soft Honey Bunches of Oats. Intensely sour finish with a subtle emerging hoppiness. I dont normally like that pine feature in tart beers, but it very much complements the lemon qualities here. World class.

Bottle 375cl, 2007 vintage. Brett smell in the nose, wood, grassy hops. Cider-like first impression, then the wooden cask taste, yeasty but refreshing aftertaste. Very interesting brew and overwhelming complex.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2014 Bottle. 2006 vintage. Pours a golden orange color with minimal head into my stemware. Very floral and funky type aromas in the nose. Im taken aback slightly as this smells like nothing Cantillon I have had before. Beyond the floral notes are some fruity and lemony aromas. The taste is quite good although again, different, from other Cantillon beers I have had before. Fairly tart and sour. Lemony aftertaste with some barnyard. Light mouthfeel. Love to try this one again. 2009 version, fantastic. Floral with some brett like notes. tasty stuff.

2006 vintage.  $25.00/ bottle at HopCat, GR, MI and worth it! It was the only style of beer that I had not tried. Dark amber color with almost no head. Wonderfully sour aroma and taste. Malt and hops must have been there---but I couldnt smell or taste them!

Draft at Blue Monk in Buffalo. Honey golden pour. Tart earthy aroma. Acidic tartness, mouth quenching. Horse blanket, barnyard funkiness. A real treat. Thanks to Matt Dinges from Shelton for setting me up!!!

bottle thanks to Savvy, you rock!  Pours hazy orange with no head.  Aroma is out of this world, sour apple, lemon, musky wood, a nice herbal grass note  as well.  Flavor is mellow apple skin, bitter citrus rind, funky barnyard yeast, and a lingering acidity.  Nice stuff.
75cl bottle. Hazy deep golden colour with a small white head. Aroma is fruity with some brett and oak. Flavour is dry, sour and fruity with oak and lemon.

Tap (2007 label). Two fingers of head that is only slightly off-white on a rich ruby red organge, slightly hazy, body. Nice funkiness in the aroma, but not overpowering.  Raspberries slightly, funky, tart, and a touch puckering...a bit acidic. Really nice.

From bottle dated Feb 17th 2010 Vintage 2007 pours golden orange with nice bubbly white head. Aroma is sour and fruity, lemon, yeast, and hay. Taste has a great sour lemon flavor, hay, grass, yeast, spices, dry. Very nice crisp and sour extremely enjoyable.

2007 vintage- poured into a Cantillon logo wine glass. Thought I would review a relatively fresh version of Iris vs. more aged versions previously had.Popped the cork and not a wisp of air- concerned about carbonation but was not an issue.  Pours dark golden/copper with a nice level of carbonation and head. Micro bubble lacing that coats the glass.Nose-  apricots, lemon, green apple, oak, but overall very fresh fruit forward. Taste- hops are definitely in the foreground- woody bitterness intertwine with the moderate acidity. Lack of wheat gives the malt more sweeter flavour to the malt. Finish is drying from the hops and cheesy.

Musty pear and granny smith apple nose. Hazy amber, medium yellow head. Musty and sour flavor of unripe strawberries, apple core, and grass. Pilsner hops in the finish, good transition from sour to bitter. Very beery for a lambic.

07 on tap at the Trappist. It pours a golden orange color with a creamy white head. The aroma is inviting with some tart fruit like lemons, cherries,  hints of Brett, leather and oak. The flavor is outstanding with a distinct wildness. Lots of oak and leather. Some lemony tartness, but well balanced by a touch of fruity sweetness and floral hops. It has a very hoppy finish of strong citrus peel and flowers that sets this apart from the other lambics Ive tried so far. Perfect body, mouthfeel, and carbonation. Loved it!

Shared bottle with Bernt at Håndverkerstuene, Oslo. Pours hazy deep golden with a small white head. Aroma of farmhouse, yeasty fruits. Taste is an explotion of fresh sourness, nice and dry, and with a lingering end, this was a good experience. Will have more of this.
Tap at the Cheeky Monk Denver.  Cloudy amber with little head.  Complex aroma of hops, peach, malt, and roses.  Apricot, caramel, hint of brandy flavor with a pronounced hop finish.  A sour pale ale.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2015 375mL 2005 thanks to the RateBeer crowd at Spuyen Duyvil. Pours a mostly flat clear orange. Aroma is citrusy, perfumey, very spicy with lots of cognac and dried orange peel. Taste is massively dry, spicy, peppery, perfumey. Not sour and very slightest tartness. Will need to crack open my 07 bottle soon to compare. 8/4/8/5/15=4.0 
375mL 2004. This vintage is much sweeter up front in both the aroma and body. More orange candies abound, tamarind candies, almost cloying sweetness. Very different and not my style. 7/4/7/4/13=3.5750mL 2005 ed. Pours a hazy, glowing deep orange with a towering, healthy, rocky off-white head. Huge retention for any beer but unreal retention for a lambic. Aroma is fresh grapefruit, white grapefruit peel and dried pomelo peel, potpourri oranges, fresh/juicy oranges, rich floral notes, heavy pepper, very present caramel, and muted but present soft house funk and fruity Brett. Taste is fresh, lightly bitter, massively lactic, soft, spritzy, and citrus heavy with an insane amount of rich complexity that is tough to describe. Tannic oak is present but not so important, bitter flowers, white pepper, grass, earth, grapefruit juice, bitter citrus, light citrus acidity. Mouthfeel is light, soft, all encompassing pillow-like carbonation with sharp, zippy lactic acidity and then finishes full oaky dry. It is just so perfect that you dont even know what to say. Unreal. 3/6/2011 9/5/9/5/17=4.5750mL 2005 ed. Pouring clear deeper orange. Thicker, creamier foam than almost any lambic Ive ever seen. Nose is very fresh red grapefruit, white grapefruit rind, tamarind, chili powder, fresh tangerine,  somethink fresh and dusty like mango powder and pollen. Taste is out of control refreshing- very sharp grapefruit, no acetic, heavy lactic, heavy citric, extreme leatheriness on the palate. Bright, quenching. So nice to have on a 90 degree DC "summer" day in April. One of my favorite beers ever. 4/10/2013 8/5/10/5/18=4.6[ 2011 Vintage ][ 750mL ][ El Cerrito Corona ][ Tasting ][ Cantillon Iris Stemware ][ 2.27.15 ]
>> Bubbly clear deep orange to almost amber pour generates a thick, rocky, yellow, persistent head. Nose is moldy red grapefruit, thick tamarind bean, juicy kumquat. Perfect flavor of leathery red grapefruit, cranberry, grapefruit rind, lime zest, saltwater. Exquisite beer that just gets better and better every time I try it. One of the best beers that exists and one that makes me proud to have chose this in lieu of champagne for my wedding toast. 9/5/10/5/19=4.8
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Hazy orange colour, large off-white head, musty. Aroma is sour fruits, bit of vinegar, yeasty. Flavour is very sour, yeasty, and fruity. Long sour finish. Very enjoyable.

Waw, what a great beer! It comes straight at all of your sences. It looks great: a cloudy amber colour with a nice head. Very lively beer, even the sound it makes when poured into the glass is great. Perfect, very complex nose. Perfectly balanced taste: acidic, sour and a some bitterness in the aftertaste. Perfection, need to get more of this stuff. (Corked Bottle 75cl, label says Iris 2006, cork says 2008 so probably brewed in 2006 and bottled in 2008)

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2012 (750 ml @ Ravintola Gloria, Kuopio. 2006 version. Rated @ 17.7.2009.)
Clear at first, but after a while the classic hazy orange colour forms. Nice and stable head. Very fruity aroma with hops, pine, apple and apricots. Extremely tart taste which creates a really dry mouthfeel. Light sweetness balances the taste. Very refreshing with a really dry finish. True Cantillon quality. 9-4-8-4-16 4.1
750 ml bottle. 2007 version.
Pours a hazy golden colour with a small head. Aroma of strong sour fruits with very strong lemon notes. Flavour of strong lemons, clove, some malts, oak and some floral notes. Mouth-drying finish of flowers, some malts and loads and loads of lemons. This is probably the best unblended lambic Ive tasted so far. 9-4-9-4-16 4.2.

Murky amber with light, off-white head / Nose of sour cherries, oak, and brett / Medium body, tart and acidic, slightly thin, with good, bitter finish / Flavors of sour cherries, oak, caramel, chrysanthemums, and barnyard brett / Very nice, in a thin, acidic style.
Finally, my first unblended lambic.  Near clear golden pour with whitish head.  Cheesy, tart, dry, seems underaged despite being a 2007.  Would be good with a cheese platter
from 2003:nice old aroma,lovly amber, hazy, minimal head, lightly bitter, medium sourness, medium body, oily feel, lively, long finish, the beer suprice me.

750ml bottle, brewed 2005 and bottled 2007. Really funky cap and really funky cork - a promising sign for a Cantillon, as always. The nose is very dry, corky, woody, and acidic. Flavor is enamel-stripping super tart; just plain sour, no questions asked. Theres a grape rind-like bitterness character, too. The whole thing is almost like sucking on a block of salt. Hops are definitely there a bit, but the sourness just cleans up shop. Powerful and delicious. I love when Cantillons get nice and sour like this.

75cl bottle at home vintage 2007. The aroma is of hops and Brett. Its like oval on steroids! One of the most inviting aromas in a beer. The taste doesnt quite live up to the aroma but its still impressive. Its quite one dimensional but still enjoyable. Though I still think that I prefer my lambics withe wheat in them. Not my favorite but not bad.

375ml into snifter. Pours a hazy straw yellow with thick medium white head. Aroma is of horse-blanket and funk. Mouthfeel is somewhat thin and full of carbonation. Flavor is pure sour goodness, you can taste the pale malt followed by the tartness of the brett and lacto. Great beer however a lower level cantillon for me.

A friend lended me some of this beer to taste, and it was quite enjoyable.  Very sour- something Im not used to, but not a bad thing.  Tangy when it first touches your tongue and then subsides into a decent aftertaste.  One of the top raters repeatedly mentioning some sort of horse blanket.  I asked google, and it had no idea what that was. I feel like that person is full of shit, and is just making stuff up.  Dont just trust random reviews!  Constant vigilance!  By the way, poured with a nice brown color.

Poured a hazy orange with a good sized white head.  Aroma is sour with fruit.  Taste is also sour with some smooth fruity notes.  Wonderfully complex with some hoppy bitter flavors.  Finish is hoppy and sour with some apples.  A great beer to celebrate rating 300!

(bottle, 75cl, vintage 2003) Hazy, orange to golden colour with a small off-white frothy layer.  Acidic citrus- and apple-fruity aroma with woody notes, a light to moderate lambic-character and slightly sweaty hops. Moderately sour and bitter flavour with a very shy malty sweetness, light to medium bodied with a mild carbonation. Dry malty Lambic-like and distinctively fruity and woody taste, becoming even dryier, almost astringent towards the woody and fruity finish with delicately hoppy notes and a restrained tartness, but with a slightly vinous feel. Very pleasant. 29.VI.10

"Botteld in 2004"

Thats what the cork says. Its streaked with yellow and smells of vinegar. Yet its more auspicious than the crown cap, which is stained with a ring of black matter. This beer should be prime drinking material. "Should" being the operative word; Cantillon bottles dont age so much as fester.

Cloudy and urine colored, it smells like a homeless person whos fallen into a crate of rancid lemons. Yellow woodsorrel, funk, and oak dominate the flavor. Missing are the algal bloom qualities of fresh Iris, but the beer remains full bodied, broad shouldered, and barrel chested.

The price difference between this and the Classic Gueuze is due probably to the hops. In that sense, aging it was a bad idea. But this is still a flavory beer. In the senses of smell, taste, and sight, yes. Age it. Can I reconcile this? Who knows? Guess Im not much of a critical drinker.

Thanks for the bottle, mikey711.
user_location: The Court of the Crimson King, California, USA

text: 12.7 oz cork and capped bottle from Canals Hainesport. Poured an orange/amber body with a huge bubbly off white head that settled down to a slight coating that floated on top of this lambic for the duration. Aroma isnt as tart or sour as I was expecting. Still a good dose of sour lemon leads the aromas along with some wood, floral notes, funk and a hint of honey. The body on this one is surprisingly drinkable with a medium mouthfeel, average carbonation and medium sour tartness that never really overpowers your palate. Flavor of woody lemons, honey, flowers and funk. This was the perfect sized bottle to be sipping alone outside on a beautiful summer evening. Actually the more I sipped this the more I wish I had opted for the 750 because this is one addictive lambic.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ amber orange with a white head.Aroma lemon ,floral hops ,sweet malt and funk.Flavour is lemon, sweet malt ,funk and hopa.Thin to medium body, hard carbonation .Very nice funky beer.
hay, floral hops, grass, citrus, barnyard, vanilla in aroma. Hazy orange,  minimal head, white foam, light sweetness, very bitter, oily feel, astringent finish

375 ml bought at the brewery, bottled 2010. Pours orange, not a lot of retaining head. Of course its sour, but not to any extreme levels. Rather, the sourness is made up of many different sour flavors such as lemon, vinegar and green grapes. Has some floral notes too, and a present, but light, bitterness. Excellent lambic, served well as my birthday treat.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2012 2005 vintage, bottled 2007, 375ml bottle.
amber colored from all barley. medium sized head, little to no lasting retention. nose has a heavy potpourri/perfumed hop scent on top of milder pedio and lacto notes (light solvent, slight barn must, horsey, mild mallo, etc.). oak is mild to medium, honey-like in flavor with a barely-discernible scent of vanilla. flavor is focused forcefully on the fresh hops, giving it both an intense hop bitterness and a wood oil resinous quality that reminds me of the bitterness and astringency of absinthe (but not the flavor). somebody else mentioned malort, which is also made from wormwood. my guess is the uncharacteristic fresh hop bitterness combined with oak barrels is responsible for this incredibly long-lasting wood oil flavor and astringency. its honestly a bit off-putting, though not offensive, but I can easily see how it would ruin the experience of this beer for people. its nothing like traditional lambic, lacking both the 1/3 raw wheat character and the acid cleanliness that comes from avoiding aroma and flavoring hops. acid is medium to low for unblended lambic, but does successfully catch the back of the tongue in a refreshing bite and burst. body is crisp, frothy and full. bitterness is heavy for the style and seems out of place and brash. the hops are disjointed and give it a green/floral/vegetal flavor that doesnt work. no surprise that this isnt how lambic naturally evolved. by the end of the bottle the wood oil and lacquer astringency becomes much more off-putting. an interesting lambic to revisit and explore more now that I know what I like much more than I did in 2004 when I initially sampled this beer. Ill keep a couple of bottles around in the cellar, but I honestly dont find this lambic appealing enough to buy and cellar cases.

vintage 2005, bottled in 2007
darker than expected.  amber/hazy orange.  med head, nice lacing.  nothing too exciting about the looks.
nose: upfront sour, yogurty, milky.  coriander, apricot baby food (possibly from pedio ethyls?), cider spices--clove, nutmeg, squash blossom, baked pumpkin, potpourri
mouth: upfront sour, but much drier than nose would indicate.  bitterness from fresh hops.  this has a very long finish, evolving in some really disgusting ways.  after the upfront sourness, theres the hoppy bitterness, which is followed by a lingering wood oil bitterness of sandalwood, dried flowers, turpentine, lacquer, gross herbals like jaeger and other bitters/amaros.  this reminds me of malort, both in flavor and the way the nastiness lingers.  after 30 seconds, theres a distinct skunkiness that overtakes the mouth and makes me want to chug anything sweet.  baking spices from the oak develop as it warms, which doesnt help anything.
the worst part is the lack of integration between the layers of flavor.  the sourness, which is actually quite pleasant, lays lightly on top, while the bitterness and oiliness below seem detached from both the expected flavors and textures.

From a bottle (2007/ bottled 2010).  Pours hazy orange with a large pillowy white head.  Acidic lemon aroma, with some floral hops, and a nice bit of funk.  The hops really come through in the aroma.  Taste is bitter and very tart and acidic.  Really good, and very refreshing.

2007 bottle. The cork was 3/4s of the way out by itself after I popped the cap. Orange amber with a large off-white head. High bead. Aroma of cider vinegar, the barn and cut flowers you should have thrown out yesterday. Taste is quite sharp and sour with loads of lemon as well as fruity vinegar. Maybe some citrus bitterness too, but its hard to pick up.  Theres a little explosion of complex sour notes just before the finish. A little wood at the end too. Theres not a lot of depth to the funk (the lack of wheat or the lack of age?) and its not really puckeringly sour - its very quaffable.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Comes in a beautiful bottle which has to be uncorked after removing top. Never had this before so I thought this would be a really exciting beer. It had the aroma of sour exotic fruits and poured very fizzy cloudy light brown. Then came the taste which was sour and rancid. I am sorry but I just couldnt drink this.

Bottle 2007.  Aroma has notes of lemons, barnyard, sour funk and cob webs.  Medium orange hue with an average sized off-white head that mostly diminished and left some lace.  Flavor is sweet, bitter, tart and sour.  Palate is medium bodied with an average carbonation.  Overall a very good brew thats sweet and refreshing.  I think a few more years would actually improve it.

Vintage 2007, tasted from 375mL bottle at Lush West Town.  Pours light amber orange with a quickly fading white head.  Nose is brett funk with some burnt rubber, vinegar, and a dandelion florality and just a hing of lemon and green apple.  Taste is very bitter on the tip of the tongue and very sour with some citrus.  The body is medium minus with sparkling carbonation and a medium finish.
A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss.

Poopy, funky, stinky cheesy, acidic lemon notes on the nose, and some earthy funky hop notes. Pretty damn funky and enjoyable. Pours hazy orange golden with not head or lace. Strongly lemony and funky. Lots of stinky cheese and barnyard, wild yeast, and poopy poop poop. More acidic tart/sour lemon in the finish. Super solid and enjoyable funk bomb.

Bottle (2003/bottled 2005): Deep golden to orangey coloured, a bit unclear, nearly medium sized - slowly collapsing - off-white head; solid dry grainy-cellary nose with a certain fruitiness (apples, lemons) and traces of wood; dry bitter-sourish flavour with a little (malty) sweetness, light to medium bodied; dry sourish-cellary finish with some malty base underneath and a dry hoppy aftertaste. Just great......

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2010 Bottle. 12.7 oz. (2007 Vintage) Split with Vin. Pours a hazy, murky turbid orange with a thin, white, creamy head. Shiny, reflective surface. Aroma of barnyard funk, sharp cheese, lemon zest, lavender, blueberry, dry hops, wild yeasts, grass, and earth. Full bodied with a smooth, creamy, roundly robust, tart palate. Notes of sharp, savory cheese in the frinish. Bit sour too. The age on this brew really balanced it nicely and gave the sour a solid, malty, floral backbone. Excellent lambic.
Sampled on tap at SIB, pours hazy orange. Aroma of sourness, citrus, lemon and floral notes. Flavour of dominated by the sourness, with some earthiness and floral notes. A treat.

Hazy orange with a thin layer of white bubbles.  Lemony sour aroma with barnyardy funk, floral and hay notes.  Taste is along similar lines but gives a more intense, puckering sour sensation and the impression of apple.  Finishes with more barnyard, hay, grass, earth, floral notes.  Pretty complex and dry, not sweet tasting at all.

2007 Bottle

A-pours a beautiful deep hazy golden amber color with a dense thinner off white head.

S-very nice nose, fresh damp wood, lots of peaches and tangeriness with hints of sourness to it, faint touch of musky cellar funk in the back.

T-soft subtle peach, notes of oaky wood, a little leather, funk subtle but does seem to be there, a good acidity in the back.

M-a little grainy, strong carbonation, light body, dry in the back.

D-pretty solid brew, nice oak aging with a good level of acidity to it, nice balance and not too sweet at all but still a good flavor and some earthy characteristics.  Very good!

750ml bottle thanks to alfrantzell on BA.  Pours a brilliant clear copper color with a small white head that fades to a thick ring.  Excellent aroma - funky and malty with some sweet malt presence as well as some oakiness.  Excellent flavor, nice and malty (no wheat in this one) with oak, barnyard, funky cheese, and even a little salt.  Significantly sour, this one is.  Sharp and biting on the palate with medium body and average carbonation.  A really excellent beer, even compared to other Cantillons.  Very drinkable.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 2004 Vintage at Capones 2009 Black Friday Event

A: Medium golden-orange-amber body. Not much of a head, but a nice tight ring maintains its form throughout. No lacing left behind.

S: Grape skins, lemon, light vinegar notes. Good sour/tart hints.

T: Similar to the nose with light, subtle notes of grape skins, apricot, and lemon. Green apple notes start to come out as the beer warmed.

M: Smooth and medium bodied. Light, but sufficient carbonation. Nice sour twinge in the back end. Lightly puckering.

O: This tasty brew was a nice demonstration of some age mellowing the power of the sour/tart notes. Refined and somewhat delicate. Nice offering from Cantillon

2007 vintage, 2010 bottle.  Pours hazy orange with thin eggshell white head.  Aroma is musty cork, some apple, pear, and other fruits, and some barnyard.  Taste is really nice and balanced, not a sour bomb by any means.  Some nice sour apple, pear, tiny bit of cheese leads into the lacto sour with some wood, must, and a nice dry finish.  While not as awesome as other Cantillons, it is still a very nice brew.

Bottle 75cl. A fuzzy orange ale with medium head ans no lacing. Smell is typically acid and moister like. As other lambic from Cantillon this product is very sour, very dry, very bitter, without intensive fruit flavor and with moisture aroma. So for me they products are very less interesting.

Bottle at Jimmys No. 43 during a Lovullo Tasting Session. Pours amber-gold with a soft, lingering white head. Plenty of bread and yeast in the aroma, along with light fruitiness. More fruit in the tart flavor, specifically lemon and strawberry. Some mild hop bite in the tail. Very dank. Lightly warming with soft carbonation. I found it akin to drinking flowers, which may or may not be your cup of tea. Pretty good, to give a highly subjective summation

Bottle, shared with Dave and Parksy. Pours a hazy burnt orange with a short-lived fizzy white head, leaving no lace. Very intriguing aroma: sour fruit and raw wood, some funky musty cork. Palate is on the lighter side, but the flavours are intense and interesting: sour apples, dry unripened pear, musty basement, oaky wood, leather, and subtle floral perfume. Finish is bitter and tart, like the soft pit inside the stone of a peach. I really enjoyed this.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Pours dark Orange with a medium size white head. Aroma of citrus hops and vinegar. Funky goodness. Lively carbonation. Nice beer

750 ml corked and capped green bottle, vintage 2007, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 6%. Deep golden to orange colour, moderate off-white head.Beguiling complex aroma, notes of farmhouse, rustic kitchen, oxidised apples, apple cider vinegar and hops. The flavour is sour but not extreme, hints of oxidised apples and spices, unlike other lambics it also has a distinct hoppy bite in the finish.

Bottle (2007 batch, bottled in 2010).  Pours a fairly fizzy orange.  Lots of fizzy head at first and earthy, sour aromas.  Flavor is really where the true greatness lies, however.  Lots of lemon, vinegar, oak.  It ends with a bit of a bitterness that seems odd... Im guessing its due to the impatience of the guy drinking the beer in this case and that after a year or ten it might fade out.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2011  Når bare bliver bedre for hver gang hvad giver man det så? citrus, grape, lemon, vinegar,amber, cloudy, tan foam, heavily sour, salty, medium body, lively, creamy, bitter, long sour finish, 
Dejlig drikkelig sur øl der passer til alt.
Tasted 2010-05-07. Sample at festival. Pours clear, golden with small white head. Bretty, sour aroma. Barnyardish taste of rotten apples. True lambic. Very tasty.

A: The pour is a really nice looking amber-orange in color with a light and fizzy white head.

S: Plenty of acidity and green fruit notes. I pick up apples and grapes with some lemon. A strong oak aroma with a somewhat subdued funk.

T: A nice tartness up front with some fresh sour apples and lemons. The back end is actually a bit bitter with lots of oak and tannins. A bit of must and leather finish things off.

M: The body is medium with a fair amount of carbonation, especially for a lambic that is so "young" in the bottle. A nice acidity and dry finish.

D: Not my favorite of the Cantillon beers, but still really nice and better than many American sours. A really pleasant beer to sip on after watching the Sharks beat the Wings.

Non-complex. Watery. Surprisingly not very sour.

Not interesting, but easier to drink than the others.

 Sampled at Ølfestivallen.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2013 Bottle. Hazy dark amber with small head. Aroma is malt, frut, tart, little barnyard, caramel and sour. Flavour is malt, fruit, tart, sour, caramel, little dark fruit and barnyard.

750mL of the 2005 vintage from Bruisin.  The cork pops off violently, though no gusher ensues. Poured into a Trappist glass this ale is very apparently cloudy with a orange colored body and an explosive white head which disappears into nothing after a minute. The aroma is bluntly sour. The blended lambics Ive tasted have a complex, woody character and a deep, layered sourness. This one lacks those deep nuances and rather displays aggressive, one-dimensional sourness with a surprising bitterness as well. Its not necessarily a bad thing, I can appreciate a "to the point" type of beer. The flavor packs lots of bitter bite, almost like grapefruit but without the full citrus character that some PNW hops can provide. I dont get any real oaky flavor that I associate with blended lambics, again making this unique.  Tart vinegar is all over the place, making for a puckering beer. The palate is medium-light with a prickly mouthfeel. Its a good beer and different, indeed. But in the end I think blends provide more bang for the buck flavor-wise.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2014 Iris 2007 bought from Beermerchants consumed at home. Slightly hazy golden copper colour. Very acidy, funky; hoppy like a double IPA and fruity too. Incredibly sour too. Good stuff but prefer other Cantillons to this. Fantastic beer though.

- Re-rate - 26th November 2011. Acid; funk; sour; wild berries; Tenders elbow grease; tart and devine drinkability. Smacks my lips for six and batters my chops around the park. I want more and Im thirsty. I love Cantillon!  - 8 - 4 - 8- 4

Bottle from Beermerchants.com. Ive had this in the cellar (well, under the stairs) since last summer. With dear old Blightys weather starting to behave like spring I thought the time has come to crack this open.
 Slightly hazy-amber pour with a white head. Musty aromas of wet grass, some citrus, cheese, heather. Crisp flavours of lemon peel, grapefruit, pineapple, lime. Very well balanced sweet/sour action. Dry, fruity mouthfeel. Very dry, acetic finish. By jove, I dont think ive found a below excellent Cantillon brew yet, hats off to them!

Pours opaque murky dark orange with a huge egg shaped head that builds constantly. Aroma of tart funky sourness, oak, fruit, herb, vinegar. Taste is sour grapefruit, very sour. Medium body, soft carbonation. Dry finish, nice balance of sweetness but definitely incredibly sour.
Bottle 0,75ltr: Another one from this Brussels greatness. Hazy amber coloured dry and vinous tasted brew.
Pours a cloudy amber color with a white head that vanishes except for the rim.  Aroma is sour, with funk, earth and lemon.  Flavor is earthy, tart, touch of hops, and barnyard funk.  Delicious!!!

2004 Vintage, 375 mL bottle.  Pours hazy orange with about 3 bubbles from a vigorous pour.  Aroma was a fantastic combination of lavender, perfume, honey, lemon and grapefruit.  Incredibly complex aroma that was even better as you drank.  This was incredibly tart that made my cheeks pucker in a good way, yet this had a unique fruity hop finish to complement the sourness.  Virtually no carb, and the finish is a great dry bitterness on the tongue.  Fantastic beer that has held up well and could go many more years.
Small bottle.  pour is cloudy yellow with thin white head.  Aroma is funk, tart, light earthy malt and light floral notes.  Flavor also tart and funky with deep, rich lambic flavors.  Great stuff.
Bottle, labelled "Iris 2003". Pours deep, slightly  cloudy amber with no head. Stable aroma. Sour prickly flavour gives way to a nice bitter aftertaste. Brilliant.
Cloudy orange, nice white head. Smells of lemon, dust, funk. Very lemony flavor, with notes of vinegar and dust. dry finish. Very tasty.
Pours cloudy amber with an off-white head. Aroma is tart, burnt rubber, leather, pine and light sweathy socks. Flavour is tart, burnt rubber, pine, light grass and grapefruit.

Bottle. A quite sour aroma, fruity, a soft hidden sweetness. The large white fizzy head gets fast smaller. The body is dark orange. The taste starts sour, then it gets mild. The body is fizzy, the finish is dry. A very nice beer.

Pours an orange/yellow colour with no head, even if poured fairly aggressively. The aroma is earthy, a little vinegary an like sweaty, spicy onions. The flavor is very sweaty, earthy, fruity and spicy. Onions, lemon, flowers, peach, vinegar, horse blanket and spice. A long bitter finish. I like this, but it just seems a little out of balance. I think another 6 months would do this some good.

750ml green bottle, corked and capped. Amber coloured liquid, cloudy. Not much of a head, what is there fades away quickly to a few surface bubbles. No lace. Nose has a light leathery component to it with a lemony, tart edge. Flavour has some sweat, brett, tart grapes. Tart and citrusy finish, acidic and dry. Medium bodied, low carboantion. Consumed outside on a warm, sunny spring day.

From the bottle at PP belgian fest. Hazy golden color with a thin white head. Aromas of barnyard earthy funkiness and floral notes. Moderate tartness and sourness. Very interesting grassy, citrus flavors yes with understated hop qualities.Finish leaves you wanting more. Awesome.
